The vulva includes the mons pubis, labia, clitoris, and vestibule.
The labia minora are covered with pubic hair.
The clitoris is an erectile organ.
The urethral orifice is located posterior to the vaginal orifice.
The hymen has no opening in a virgin (virgo intacta).
Bartholin's glands open on either side of the urethral orifice.
The perineum is located between the vulva and the anus.
The ovaries are responsible for producing estrogen and progesterone.
The fallopian tubes are the site of fertilization.
The infundibulum is the part of the fallopian tube attached to the uterus.
The uterus is a hollow, muscular organ.
The endometrium is the outermost layer of the uterus.
The broad ligament is a strong, fibrous ligament that is the main support of the uterus.
The vagina has an alkaline pH to protect against infection.
The true pelvis is above the pelvic brim and has no obstetric importance.
The true conjugate is the shortest anteroposterior diameter of the pelvic inlet.
The gynecoid pelvis is the most common type in females.
The fetal skull bones of the face and base are fused and do not allow molding.
The anterior fontanelle is triangular in shape.
The sacrospinous ligament runs from the sacrum to the ischial tuberosity.
The Skene's glands secrete mucus to lubricate the urethral opening.
The fourchette is formed by the posterior fusion of the labia minora.
The ovary is attached to the broad ligament by the mesovarium.
The ampulla is the narrowest part of the fallopian tube.
The external os is the opening between the isthmus and the cervix.
The round ligament passes through the inguinal canal.
The pouch of Douglas is an anterior relation of the vagina.
The anatomical transverse diameter is the smallest diameter of the pelvic inlet.
An android pelvis is a typical male pelvis shape.
The lambdoid suture is between the parietal and frontal bones.
